Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Also doesn't help that the general public doesn't care about crypto. It's just too friggin complicated to get and use especially when things like venmo is so easy. I'd prefer a retro approach,  user printable stable coin notes for gifts, trading, and gambling.

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Holding a $10 stable coin note in my hand will make it seem very legit, and easy enough to send by any grandma.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the problem is counterfeits

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let us imagine a $10 stable coin note that has a paper wallet inside, it cant be outside as then anybody can see the privkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but if it is inside, you cant verify it

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Hmmm, I guess it would be used by people who trust one another. The other group who doesn't trust each other, maybe it works with an app to verify the note has what it says on it, or just instantly transfer it. Maybe some form of zero knowledge proof would be included. All of this, way above my head. But I mention this as a way to affect UX. A new series on Netflix,(the toys that made us) details the rise of starwars , he-man, gijoe, etc figures. Holding a physical toy made the characters "more" real. It is in this concept that I envisioned a physical crypto note.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe it can be a minituarized ledger type of device without any pin. so possession of it allows you to spend whatever is in it and you can verify what is in it, along with proof of the privkey

Author: Alright#0419
Content: such devices exist already, but they still rely on trust

Author: Alright#0419
Content: can try to find what it is called if anyone is interested

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: done properly, it could be trustless

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @polycryptoblog that guy in NY had one, do you recall the name of it?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess you need to prevent the privkey from ever leaving the device. which of course is likely impossible

Author: Alright#0419
Content: the way it was explained to me, it was flawed. Basically it was an nfc chip, you could use it to check pubkey(and therefore balance)

Author: Alright#0419
Content: but I was thinking just change the pubkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but maybe you can make it so that an untampered device can be known to not revealed privkey

Author: Alright#0419
Content: was a tiny hardware wallet essentially, couldn't extract keys from it from what he claimed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: pubkey is no proof of privkey, it needs to be able to sign it and also not allow the privkey to ever be extracted

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with all the sidechannel and clever attacks against a physical device, it seems doubtful that it can be protected against.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but if it was only $10, then maybe it isnt worth extracting

Author: Alright#0419
Content: if you were going to accept one as payment, you would need a computer to check balance anyway

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so we need to wait a few more generations until secure hardware wallets can be 10 cents each

Author: Alright#0419
Content: at that point, use a normal hardware wallet

Author: Alright#0419
Content: hardware wallets built into the average cell phone seems to me like it'll accomplish the same thing

Author: Alright#0419
Content: that is already happening, and seems objectively better than any device that would physically change hands each transaction
